segments.text: I'm Sean interviewing Carl Sagan on October 19, 1993, at Boulder, Colorado.
Now, Carl, for the record, would you give us your full name?
My name is Carl Edward Sagan.
Okay, and when and where were you born?
November 9, 1934, Brooklyn, New York.
When did you first get interested in astronomy?
About age five.
What part of astronomy did you get interested in, and how did that happen?
I describe this in my book, Cosmos, and it's done much better there than I can do it here.
It's chapter six, I think.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
I got all my earned degrees, all four of them, at the University of Chicago.
When did you get your bachelor's degree?
I got...
A BA in 1954 and a BS in physics in 1955.
Did you ever take any astronomy classes as an undergraduate?
As an undergraduate?
No, I did not.
Why did you go to Chicago?
I went to Chicago because it had the only planetary astronomer in the United States and I wanted to do planets.
That was Gerard Kuiper, and also because the physics and chemistry departments were extremely good.
The names Enrico Fermi and Harold Urey attracted me.
But what I didn't realize is that on showing up, I was subjecting myself to the Hutchins baccalaureate program in which they said that my showing up showed that I didn't know any subjects.

and therefore it was up to them to tell me what to study, and so they had 14-year-long courses that were required for the bachelor's degree, which had almost nothing to do with professional pursuit of mathematics, physics, and astronomy, and it was the best thing that ever happened to me because I was too narrowly focused, and it broadened me up.
You'll recall there was a little to-do about some magazine.
You mentioned that Kuiper was the only practicing planetary astrophysicist in the 50s or whatever, and someone said,
Why did you say that?
You said, because it's true.
Could you give us the detail?
Well, I learned this from talking to other astronomers, which I did before going to, you know, before applying.
But, you know, think about it.
Who else was anything close to a full-time planetary astronomer in the United States?
At the time, not John Strong, Robert Richardson at Mount Wilson.
I just don't think there were any others, but there was Kuiper.
This is 1951 I'm talking about.

Darius Kuiper had just edited the atmospheres of the Earth and planets, had discovered CO2 on Mars, methane on Titan, was trying to understand the origin of the solar system, was involved in theory and observation, and was also not completely hostile to the idea of life elsewhere.
He was doing great guns, and there was, as far as I know then or now, nobody else.
Were you aware that, let's put it this way, at least some part of the astronomical establishment, anywhere from half to 99%, considered planetary astronomy a third-rate field at that time?
I can't remember if I was truly aware of that at the time.
I certainly became aware of it quickly thereafter.

the people who I asked for advice, for example, Lyman Spitzer at Princeton, did not think planetary science was a third-rate field, maybe in part because Lyman had done some planetary science himself.
He was, for example, the source of the then primary objection to the
jean's jeffrey's view of the origin of the solar system by the close encounter of two stars and had also been doing work on the escape of planetary atmospheres
So maybe I had to buy a sample, but in any case, by the time I got to Chicago and talked to some of the stellar astronomers there, it got across to me very strongly.

If I had known about it beforehand, it wouldn't have affected me in the least, because I knew exactly what I was interested in, and no rational argument would have dissuaded me, much less an irrational argument.
So what was your doctoral dissertation?
My doctoral dissertation was called...
physical studies of planets, which was very broad to encompass a bunch of things.

The main part of it, by far, was something called the radiation balance of Venus, which was an attempt to show that the high microwave brightness temperature of Venus, as found by Cornell Mayer and others, by ground-based radio telescopes,
had, as its most natural explanation, a massive greenhouse effect in which carbon dioxide and water vapor played the main role.
And there were some subsidiary parts to it, one of which was work I had done partly with Stanley Miller on the radiation chemistry of a simulated Jovian atmosphere in which we...
I think it's the first time anyone had done a laboratory study of...
jovian atmosphere in which we made simple organic molecules, almost all of which have now been discovered on Jupiter.
Who was your thesis advisor?
Koepper.
What was he like?
That's a very complicated question.
No, the question is very simple.
It's a very complicated answer.
For me, he was, as far as the science goes, tremendously stimulating, a source of
information on absolutely everything from the Tisserand criterion in celestial mechanics to the lifestyles of lichens.
He was the first person I ever saw given a fresh problem to literally do a back-of-the-envelope calculation.
I mean literally on the back of an envelope.
The power of knowing
enough first principles physics to address a new problem just off the top of your head and see if proposed solutions came anywhere close was truly breathtaking to me.
And this was before I had seen it in any of my physics classes.
I saw it in Gerard's hands.
And he was a strongly supportive person.
of my interests, as strange as some of them were.
I was interested in extraterrestrial life, among other things.
He was temperamental.
He had his quarrels with other scientists, but he was entirely supportive of me, including finding ways for me to supplement my income.
And another thing which I very much appreciate is that he did not force a doctoral thesis on me.
He let me generate my own topics, which I, especially in retrospect, very much appreciate.
I want to skip now because we don't have very much time.
Well, I remember when the journal Icarus first came out.
It seemed to me it was full of mostly celestial mechanics from former East Block astronomers that I never heard of.
And then you became editor in the early 60s.
How did that happen?
How did they talk you into it, or did you talk yourself into it?
No, no, I didn't talk myself into it.
I don't fully understand why Zdenek Kopal and A.G. Wilson...
decided not to be editors anymore, or were asked by academic press not to be editors.
I just don't know that information, and I never asked.
But what I do know is I was asked.
They had asked me to be an associate editor from the beginning, and I was happy to do that.
That was fun.
And I published a few papers in there.
I did not do anything in the way of editorial function.
And then they came to me together and asked if I would be interested in replacing them as editor.
And I was really quite young and very flattered.
It seemed to me to be a great thing to do, a wonderful way to find out what's happening in the field.
And I had very definite ideas about how to improve the journal, one of which was to have referees, which, while not a novel idea in general, was novel for Icarus.
And for some reason, which I don't know, I mean, I generally don't know, and it wasn't a thing that I felt comfortable asking, I don't know why they chose me.

There was a feeling, a very strong feeling among the few people who were doing planetary astronomy at that time, that the Astrophysical Journal just didn't want to publish any astronomy, and this held for radio astronomy too, planetary astronomy.
And it helped for radio as well.
My first publication was in the Proceedings of the IRE.
So there was a definite need for Icarus.
How did you go about getting the papers?
Okay, let me say, I mean, I've heard this about Apjay, but my experience was that, I mean, I sent a bunch of papers to Apjay in the 60s, and they were all refereed and accepted and
There was one wild paper that Russ Walker and I sent called On the Detectability of Dyson Civilizations, which was also published.
So I never experienced that hostility at Apchang.
But others have mentioned it, and I can't make rhyme or reason of it.
But as to how I solicited papers for Icarus, well, you know, there was a small number of people, and I said to them, look, we're doing well, we're concentrating on planetary science.
Here is a journal in which you find only planetary science papers, not diluted by a vast array of papers on quite different subjects.
And there are no paid charges, and
We have glossy stock, and that means we can print nice renditions of photographs.
And some papers I solicited.
I said to someone, so you're the right person to review this subject.
It needs a broad perspective.
Why don't you do that for Icarus?
But a lot of papers came unsolicited.
And, you know, as soon as a few good papers were published, then other people noticed it.
And it prospered.
There's a sort of exponential built into it.
What do you think the status of planetary astronomy is today among, quote, real, unquote, astronomers?
Well, I think the degree of respectability has improved dramatically.
Nevertheless, there is still the sense in many people's mind of respectability being directly proportional to distance or maybe to a high power of the distance of the astronomical object examined.
And since the planets are nearby, they're considered disreputable.
In part, this is
I think due to excesses by such people as Percival Lowell.
But it's a kind of snooty attitude, which...
I think is best to simply avoid.
I mean, just ignore.

One thing I noticed is that when the government started spending large amounts of money on planetary science, especially sending spacecraft to the planets, the respectability of planetary science made a dramatic increment.
While you were editor of Vickers, what fraction of your time did you spend on the journal?
It wasn't vast.
Maybe...
I don't know.
It's hard to estimate.
If I were to give very broad limits, I would say between 10% and 25%, something like that.
And it varied from month to month and year to year.
I should say that at a critical time, I had the luck to have Steve Soder as assistant editor, and that really helped a lot.
How did Icarus get to be the official journal of the Division for Planetary Science of the American Astronomical Society?
Well, here was Icarus just being published by a commercial publisher, and here was DBS, which I had helped found, having no journal affiliated with it.
And there were other institutions, professional societies that had their journals, lots of them.
American Geophysical Union had Journal of Geophysical Research and so on.

It was such a natural idea, and so I pushed it, and then there was a time when I was president of the DPS, and I had a chance to push it harder, and people saw the wisdom of it, and nobody was trying to force any editorial policy down people's throats.
There's an appointed advisory board that has a lot to say about what happens, and
It was just an obvious marriage to be made, and I had the pleasure of being the marriage broker.
What do you think is the current status and the outlook for the near future for planetary astronomy?
Up, down, hanging in there?
Planetary astronomy or planetary science?
Both.
Well, you know, it depends very much on funding.

And funding depends very much on Congress, and Congress depends very much on the health of the national economy and also the sense that taxpayers have about this being something worth spending money on.
And all these items are very hard to predict.
The practical question is if a bright, young, motivated,
scientist comes to me starting graduate school and says, I want to be a planetary scientist, would you recommend that I do it or not?
I still, by and large, recommend that they do it.
And so that's... Well, that's true.
That's absolutely right.
And certainly the number, absolute number of jobs available today is vastly more than it was in the 50s in any kind of astronomy.
But still, if you thought the thing was headed towards some free-fall collapse, you wouldn't recommend that students pursue their interest there.
I don't think we're in desperate straits, although it's very hard when you don't know about continuity of funding and all sorts of programs started and stopped seemingly whimsically.
It's very tough, especially for the younger people.
You know, if you have
If you have tenure or you've been successful in research programs, you have some likelihood of continuity, but young people don't.
And the thing I'm most worried about is not the older folks, but the really young people.
There I'm worried that we're not preserving our options for the future as we ought.
Do you think that planetary scientists and planetary astronomers have done a good job in selling themselves to the public and to the Congress?
No and no.
I think that planetary missions have done an excellent job of selling planetary science to the public and the Congress.
Of course, in the context of the Cold War,
Many people understood each planetary mission triumph as another way that we beat the Russians, and that put a particular skew to public appreciation.
But despite that, I think understanding these missions for their own sake, for their true merit, did get through.
Now that we have lots of improved visual techniques, including false color photography and virtual reality movies,
in which we dive down to a planetary surface, we have extraordinary tools to interest the public in what we do, which I still think we don't use adequately enough.
And I think many scientists, if the funding dried up, would suddenly say, oh my goodness, I wish we had spent more time on popularizing what we do with the general public.

What impact, if any, do you think the fact that we haven't found any traces of life anywhere else in the solar system, and in particular not on Mars, what effect, if any, do you think that's had on funding?
I don't think it's had any perceptible effect on funding.
If you look at the NASA expenditures for robotic missions, you see a big blip for Viking.
But if you subtract, which I think is attributable to the interest in the search for life, but apart from that, it's reasonably flat.
So I don't think there was a depression after Viking.
We just returned to where we were in any case.
And I think if NASA had had the courage to follow up Viking with further searches for life or life-oriented understanding of the past environment of Mars, they could have maintained the Viking blip.
This is a different sort of a question.
The former Soviet Union had a lot of people called astronomers and space scientists and all this, and they really didn't do much.
Do you have an opinion as to why?
Yeah, because they were living in the former Soviet Union.
I mean, you know, you can criticize some people didn't get a good education and there wasn't adequate peer review.
especially with people who were politically connected, and Soviet scientists weren't willing to criticize each other in international forums for patriotic reasons, and all of that.
But the fundamental reason, I believe, is that the living conditions were impossibly hard.
And I was continually amazed when we go over there to see the circumstances in which not just any astronomers, the best astronomers were living.
And I remember seeing the little...
alcove that Shklovsky and P. Kellner and Kaplan had to share at the...
Sorry, I've forgotten the Astronomical Institute of the University of Moscow.
It's named after somebody.
Sternberg.
The Sternberg Astronomical Institute.
And that was very good conditions compared to living arrangements.
standing in line for food and all of that.
It is remarkable that anything was accomplished by Soviet astronomers.
What do you think is the best piece of work you've done so far?
I tend not to try to pick out bests and worsts.
Maybe one thing that I'm pleased about is that my interest in the search for life elsewhere
led me to all sorts of things completely unconnected with life.
In trying to understand the habitability of Venus, I was drawn irresistibly to the conclusion that the surface was far too hot for life.
In trying to understand the seasonal changes on Mars, which had been widely attributed to the growth and seasonal decay of vegetation,
led irresistibly to windblown dust.
So I guess one thing I'm pleased about is that my interest in extraterrestrial life did not prevent me, in fact led me to a wide range of other subjects with quite different physics.
Look at the difference between aeolian transport and
And greenhouse radiative balance and search for life are quite different.
But I've done a whole lot of things, and some of them I'm very pleased with, and others I wish I had done better on.
I may have asked you this, but I'll ask again.
Do you think planetary astronomy is part of astronomy?
Sure, sure.
And you might say that spacecraft make it somewhat non-astronomical.
If you can fly to orbit, land on a world, then why would you spend any time peering at it through a ground-based telescope?
And to a large extent, that's true.
But there are lots of worlds we can't fly to, or can't fly to often.
And we are shortly going, I think very likely, going to be...
examining planets around other stars that we surely are not going to be flying to shortly.
And that means that ground-based and near-Earth-based planetary science is going to be with us for a very long time.
And that kind of stuff, that kind of science, is a part of astronomy.
What's the role of NASA money been in resurrecting what was essentially a dead field?
absolutely fundamental.
NASA, as far as funding goes and other kinds of support, never mind space missions.
Just on the ground-based end of things and the theoretical end of things and the laboratory simulation end of things has been absolutely essential in the renaissance of this field.
And then if you add
this astonishing capability that we now have to go to other planets and see what they're like.
NASA's role is key, central, and historic for all the arteriosclerotic problems with NASA these days.
What's your opinion of how NSA manages the planetary program?
Do they micromanage?
Do they do about the right thing?
Again, a personal view.
There's so many aspects, and it's been so variable over the years, it's really hard to give a one-bit yes or no answer.
I would say that given the existing funding constraints, NASA has not been orders of magnitude too generous or too impecunious.
But if you ask me whether it's made wrong decisions,
and fail to see something which was tremendously promising or spend lots of money on something which was a dead end or scientifically not very exciting, of course that's happened.
It's happened a lot, perhaps too much.
But overall, I think for all its flaws, NASA has done a fantastic job in the support of planetary science.
